page.title: 10Housing in Whaddon
page.content: The houses of Whaddon (pop. 400) are along a winding road from Horwoods to Calverton. The oldest part of the village, between the church & Whaddon Hall follows an escarpment which gives pleasing views to Nash in the west. These older houses, mostly dating from the 19th century with some earlier ones are built of a local brick. Their styles reflect the agricultural nature of the community with large farmhouses & small cottages. Much conversion work has been done: Whaddon Hall itself is now luxury flats and the gatehouses and stables are private homes. On the outskirts of the village are more recent houses built between 1920 and the 1980s. About half the total houses come into this category. The over- riding impression is of variety: large detached houses, 1930s semis, council & elderly person dwellings.
